ratings.comment: Clearly knew what he was talking about and always had a good plan for seminars, even if we didn't always get through it all. He is a hard grader on papers (one a week!!) so I would recommend visiting the history lab to get them looked over. He's a nice guy but can get a little moody + definitely plays favorites (it's not too bad though)

Professor Rosenhagen is a kind person and seems to care about his students, however the course is very reading intensive and you will be expected to write at least 3 large papers over the semester. His prompts and grading criteria are extremely unclear, so it can be hard to get a good grade on these larger assignments. The class can also be awkward

Prof. Rosenhagen seems like a kind guy, but this class was a mess; he assigned a group project (not on the syllabus) right before the final essay, and halfway through the semester he assigned myself and another honors student an 8-10 page essay (more work than Ive EVER had for an honors class.) Couldnt hold discussions to save his life, very dry.

He is knowledgeable and wants to get us to think for ourselves, but it often ends up with the students spinning in circles on a topic and him trying to guide us to an answer that we are struggling to get on our own. Nothing has been been put into canvas' grade book, so I only have an idea of what my grade is, based off feedback from the papers.

Mixed feelings about the class. The theory is very obscure and he makes you relate it to the readings which means you really have to engage with the material to get a decent grade. He doesn't lecture, but I wish he would because he's a very smart guy. The whole 75-minute class is basically spent discussing the readings, which gets awkward & boring

I can't recommend Dr. Rosenhagen, even though I really want to. He's a good guy and is incredibly passionate about what he does. However, he is incredibly unclear with essay prompts and what he expects of students in general. You can expect to write about 30 pages of papers in total and read from 100-300 pages a week (sometimes double-sided).

UR was a very nice professor and clearly cared about the material, but the lectures had a tendency to get pretty dry. He was also lacking when it came to a sense of humor, which almost became funny in itself. Overall, not bad.

He did an amazing job with this course- really cares about the topics and does an excellent job teaching about each topic. It should be a requirement for all UW students to take this course. I think everyone in the course really enjoyed it. Long papers, but its a Com-B course and it definitely was worth it.

He isn't very specific on what he asks, but very specific on what he wants back. We spent a lot of time watching videos. Does not stay true to the course objective. He took something I was interested in and turned it into torture.

At first was unsure about class moving slowly but he just takes time to fully consider what his students say and everyone has time to think about and critically engage with material. He really wants students to succeed, and he is very smart. I improved greatly over the course of the semester with just a two brief meetings outside class.

UR is so smart, but certainly not in an intimidating way. RS600 is all theory, and he tries his best to explain everything, while at the same time allowing the students to interact as well. The class was three papers and two short presentations. Totally doable. He's a tough grader, but his feedback on the papers is helpful. Definitely recommend.
DON'T BUY THE BOOK. use a computer and copy his notes word for word

Professor Rosenhagen is a good hearted, lovable guy. He is German and a Lutheran pastor, but he doesn't show any bias in his teaching about other religions and presents things very objectively (which can be very tricky). He is a push-over. My class got him to push back a midterm and send out a study guide. The only grades are tests and attendance.
This is a very interesting class with a great professor. Reading is hard to keep up with but tests are based 90% on lecture.

Has quite the accent, and also a tendency to drift off-topic a bit. But he knows the material thoroughly, and shows an interest in both the subject matter and the students. Lectures could be a bit more gripping, but overall a good professor and fantastic course.
